<div class="post-text" itemprop="text">
<p>The images encoding should come from the client, this is how you can know which format of each one has. Example:</p>
<pre><code>base_64 = "data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhPQBEAPeoAJosM//AwO/AwHVYZ/z595kzAP/s7P+goOXMv8+fhw/v739......
</code></pre>
<p>You will receive it from the client and you know that is a .gif</p>
<p>Once you have validated the extensions and the base64 you can convert it to images and save it in your OS:</p>
<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2323128/convert-string-in-base64-to-image-and-save-on-filesystem-in-python?utm_medium=organic&amp;utm_source=google_rich_qa&amp;utm_campaign=google_rich_qa">Convert string in base64 to image and save on filesystem in Python</a> or <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/26070547/decoding-base64-from-post-to-use-in-pil?utm_medium=organic&amp;utm_source=google_rich_qa&amp;utm_campaign=google_rich_qa">Decoding base64 from POST to use in PIL</a> </p>
<p>Once you have the images in your OS, you can link them to your ImageField in the model changing the <code>name</code> property: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/8332443/set-djangos-filefield-to-an-existing-file?utm_medium=organic&amp;utm_source=google_rich_qa&amp;utm_campaign=google_rich_qa">Set Django's FileField to an existing file</a></p>
<p>I hope that is clear and helpful!!</p>
</div>
<div class="post-text" itemprop="text">
<p>Short answer is : </p>
<pre><code>import imghdr
extension = imghdr.what(file_name, decoded_file)
</code></pre>
<p>ref : <a href="https://docs.python.org/2/library/imghdr.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://docs.python.org/2/library/imghdr.html</a> OR <a href="https://docs.python.org/3/library/imghdr.html" rel="nofollow noreferrer">https://docs.python.org/3/library/imghdr.html</a></p>
<p>Basically <strong>import imghdr</strong> is the key in function <strong>Base64ImageField.get_file_extension</strong> to get / extract the extension of the function. </p>
<p>With below class extend / code you don't need to do <strong>modelJob.instance.imageA.save(content=content,name="image.jpeg")</strong></p>
<p>You need to add this class in your codebase to call or for trial purpose you can add in same Serializer class file itself. </p>
<pre><code>from django.core.files.base import ContentFile
import base64
import six
import uuid

class Base64ImageField(serializers.ImageField):
    """
    A Django REST framework field for handling image-uploads through raw post data.
    It uses base64 for encoding and decoding the contents of the file.

    Heavily based on
    https://github.com/tomchristie/django-rest-framework/pull/1268

    Updated for Django REST framework 3.
    """

    def to_internal_value(self, data):                
        # Check if this is a base64 string
        if isinstance(data, six.string_types):
            # Check if the base64 string is in the "data:" format
            if 'data:' in data and ';base64,' in data:
                # Break out the header from the base64 content
                header, data = data.split(';base64,')

            # Try to decode the file. Return validation error if it fails.
            try:
                decoded_file = base64.b64decode(data)
            except TypeError:
                self.fail('invalid_image')

            # Generate file name:
            file_name = str(uuid.uuid4())[:12] # 12 characters are more than enough.
            # Get the file name extension:
            file_extension = self.get_file_extension(file_name, decoded_file)

            complete_file_name = "%s.%s" % (file_name, file_extension, )

            data = ContentFile(decoded_file, name=complete_file_name)

        return super(Base64ImageField, self).to_internal_value(data)

    def get_file_extension(self, file_name, decoded_file):
        import imghdr

        extension = imghdr.what(file_name, decoded_file)
        extension = "jpg" if extension == "jpeg" else extension

        return extension
</code></pre>
<p>One more information is you can have </p>
<pre><code>Base64ImageField(
        max_length=None,
        use_url=True,
        required=False,
        allow_null=True,
        allow_empty_file=True
    )
</code></pre>
<p>these params in case you want to make this optional. </p>
<p>NOTE :: I had got this code from StackOverflow only, but not remembered from where I got this I had liked this answer too. </p>
</div>
<div class="post-text" itemprop="text">
<p>Here is how I solved this problem. None of the answers above had this information</p>
<blockquote>
<p>However there are two problems with this approach first of all I do
  not know the extension.How do I extract an extension ?</p>
</blockquote>
<p>The extension can be extracted by using the following code</p>
<pre><code>from PIL import Image
decodedbytes = base64.decodebytes(str.encode(image_content))
image_stream = io.BytesIO(decodedbytes)
image = Image.open(image_stream)
filetype = image.format #Contains the extension
</code></pre>
<blockquote>
<p>The next thing is Ill have to check for imageA,B,C,D and E if they
  exist and then save each one individually. If I could come up with a
  dynamic solution close to something that I have that would work as
  well.
  The solution to this was simple to use</p>
</blockquote>
<pre><code>getattr(job_inst, field).save(content=data , name="img"+filetype)
</code></pre>
